Title: Re-programming Sa'o, pursuing sustainable architecture in Ngada traditional house: A recommendation
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Interior Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Chadijah, S., Interior Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Fajarwati, A.A.S., Interior Design Department, School of Design, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Traditional house is cultural heritage owned by a nation recognized with its identity and history, memory, and culture. On its development in this modern era, buildings that was created by its local values have changed on its function and utilization. Sa'o as traditional house of Ngada people likewise has changed in interpretation and function. Through adaptive reuse, it became most popular approach in the earlier 21th century along with sustainability issue in architecture. Altering the interior spaces can achieve the conception of adaptive reuse which creates sustainability. This concept is related to culture, economic, and environmental aspect. This research offers recommendation to undertake adaptive reuse concept in Sa'o traditional house in order to gain preservation and commercial value. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: adaptive reuse; re-programming; space orientation; space zoning; traditional house
Index Keywords: History; Houses; Adaptive re use; Cultural heritages; Environmental aspects; Interior space; Re-programming; Sustainability issues; Sustainable architecture; Traditional house; Sustainable development
